item.title: Influence, Inequality, & Monocultures on the Internet
item.description: This isn’t a particularly cogent post. I intend to come back to this as I work through the ideas. One question from the great participants at INDE-21 has stayed with me, months after the conference: Given what you’ve shown and argued about elite users, is there something about them or the associations that they form that would help us intervene and alter the dynamics of that subreddit?

item.title: From Docker to Singularity and Back Again
item.description: Okay, I’ll admit it: As a practicing data scientist/junkie, I picked up Docker only after spending days trying to install the unholy combination of nvidia-cudatoolkit packages for PyTorch on my laptop with a measly GPU.

item.title: Defining a User's Home Community
item.description: Questions of Time, Power, Praise The notion of a ‘home’ community seems pretty unique to Reddit, since it has self-contained subreddits.

item.title: Experience gets you to appreciate the Fundamentals
item.description: I’m writing this as I wait to be assigned to an RCC compute node for my thesis work. It took me the better part of a day, but I think I know how to solve my large-scale entropy calculation conundrum.

item.title: Visualizing Reddit circa 2017
item.description: While working with the Reddit data dumps for Ideolect, Jeremiah and I have often used the metaphor of the Reddit Universe: groups of subreddits form their own solar systems, with some long-range connections between others.

item.title: Research Gatekeeping & Academia
item.description: This post stems from a big personal grouse of mine, and this twitter thread captures that perfectly. I didn’t want to reply on there because a) complex conversations on Twitter sucks, and b) this wasn’t my conversation to butt into.

item.title: Pandemic & Grad-School
item.description: Spending time with pip has given me a more close-up window of insight into her life in graduate school. I’ve wondered how she and her students deal with coursework and research that deal with truly horrifying topics – sexual violence, genocide, structural patriarchy.

item.title: Demographic Bias in Model Design and Big Tech
item.description: In today’s weekly CSS Workshop, we had a duo from AirBnB presenting work on ‘Designing for Trust’ in the context of the sharing economy.
